input_text:
In a quiet corner of the old city, there stood a clockmaker’s shop, its windows filled with timepieces of every size and shape. Few customers came anymore; the world had grown too fast for ticking gears and polished brass. Yet the clockmaker, Mr. Alwin, continued his work with steady hands, winding springs and adjusting pendulums as if tending to living things.

One evening, as the rain pattered against the cobblestones, a young boy wandered in. He was drawn not by the clocks, but by a strange glow from the back of the shop. Mr. Alwin, without a word, beckoned him closer.

There, hidden behind a velvet curtain, stood a clock unlike any other. Its face shimmered like moonlight, and its hands moved not in hours or minutes but in constellations. With each turn, stars shifted across its surface, mapping skies the boy had never seen.

“This one,” the clockmaker whispered, “does not measure time. It measures possibility.”

The boy leaned closer, mesmerized. In its shining glass, he glimpsed futures unfolding—some wondrous, some terrifying, all waiting beyond the present moment.

By morning, the clock and the boy were gone. Only Mr. Alwin remained, smiling faintly, as though another destiny had just begun.
summary: An aging clockmaker, Mr. Alwin, maintains his nearly forgotten shop until a boy discovers a hidden clock that doesn't measure time, but possibilities.  The boy glimpses various futures within the clock's shimmering face, and disappears with it by morning, leaving Mr. Alwin with a knowing smile.
